commentBody: I can not tell you how much I appreciate that the theme answers still make legitimate words by themselves (TAKEI, TONYA, etc)!  It's one of my pet peeves when the answers are things like FONEINGROCKZALL (which is an actual NYT crossword theme answer from 2020).
I had IBEENBAD, so I floundered badly in the SW corner. This one had me scratching my head for a good while. Interesting theme.

"But what if we read it from left to right until we get to the I, and then read up until the next black square and down again?"

I thought it couldn't happen, but today's offering has actually made me wish for a rebus puzzle instead. This makes nooo sense.

Very clever construction.  However, I failed to appreciate it while solving.  I got the revealer easily enough and figured the starred answers had to go up and probably back down.  For the life of me, however I just couldn’t make sense of the couple I took a shot at, sons just went ahead and solved using the crosses without making sense of the answers to the starred clues.  It wasn’t until I looked at the completed puzzle that the pattern became clear.  Face palm.

To quote my teenage nephew: “Bruh.” Lots of proper names and general miscellany but light on clever clues that made me say “Ahhhh, I get it now.” Small thing, but I got stuck on smart TVs having a DVR. Do they? Did they ever? I’ve had cable boxes with DVRs, and now it’s part of my streaming service. Smart TVs typically indicate internet access and apps, not recording technology. Maybe I’m wrong.
I found this tedious. I never got the gimmick until I read the blog. Oh well.
Nice one, this. Thanks!
It clicked with me, so +1 for the enjoyers.
The obvious cleverness required to construct this decidedly did not translate into pleasure for the solver. Too clever by half; the aha moment was replaced by relief that it was over.
Not a fun one for me.  I’m not a fan of overly gimmicky puzzles.
Struggled with this one. I needed all the help Deb could give me on the theme.  I always appreciate a constructor who can do something like this. Good on you, Simeon!

Was looking for a quick Thursday. This wasn’t it. 
But it was clever. I really struggled with it, more than I should have, given I figured out the theme pretty early. 

I was really hamstrung by fill that I thought were gimmies.  Like paver for MASON. Match for AGREE. Bland for ICIER.  

that said. If I was more relaxed and not trying to power solve.  I think I would have enjoyed it more. But that’s on me.  But gold, at least. 

I’m not a fan at all of IBEENHAD.  It’s the expression, “I’ve been had?”  And DVRs aren’t really features of smart TVs, are they?  I don’t think like a Samsung, has a built in DVR. It’s more like a service than a feature. Methinks. 

But I think some clever non themer cluing.  It was definitely “Thursday worthy.”

Thanks Simeon.
Perfect Thursday puzzle. Capital on the Med and musical appreciation clues especially nice. And some (but not all) of the “tricks” solved by crosses. Nice work

Thanks to all who are saying they didn’t get the theme, even after the puzzle was solved, I’m feeling very smart today! I got it relatively early in my solve. I enjoy these types of puzzles. Keep them coming.
Tricky but fun!
I was excited - perhaps the ‘features of some stadia’ would at last be vomitoria - but it was not to be. Oh well, another day another puzzle to have a crack at.

Off to a good start and enjoying the bouncy theme. Came here to rejoice over ZORK, an early classic of the Interactive Fiction (IF) genre. I suppose it was a "PC game" in a sense, but ZORK was originally a mainframe game devised at MIT. I first encountered it on the Commodore VIC-20, and I've been a huge fan of IF ever since. Adventure, Colossal Cave, Infocom, the Inform parser, the Interactive Fiction Database ...  I know way too much trivia about this topic, don't get me started!

> DOWN
It is pitch black. You might get eaten by a grue.
> LIGHT LAMP
💡

Anybody else love this stuff as much as I do?
No thank you

IBEENHAD is not a thing. 

Smart TVs do not have DVRs.

If someone is the PERP[etrator] in a TV show, they're probably not an extra, they'd be a main character.

Overall, an unenjoyable puzzle, even after figuring out the gimmick. Just a real slog to complete, even with cheating.

Cute, and pretty simple to complete once you get the revealer answer.  This was exactly what I expect for a Thursday.  At first the theme fill seemed easy - "take in" reading only down and "reserves" also reading only down.  But what does that make "bit tender"?  How is that a person with a cause?  Something else was up.  So things only became clearer after getting the revealer clue.  Then ensued a modicum of delight as I mostly breezed through the rest, still experiencing some awkward hesitation before getting the last theme up / down with radar.  "Tone award" also slowed me down for a hot second.

I really enjoyed this construction.  Thursdays should always be this level of cleverness.  Thanks!

“Capital on the Mediterranean” was very tough but clever. “Old wide screen format” I thought for sure was PANORAMA but no. 

Multiple plurals ending in i? You don’t see that very often. 

Also, I’m guessing KLEE sounds like “clay”? I could only get that one with the crossers.
No, just no.

I had the same reaction to PERP. (At one point when I had P__P I considered ProP, as in playing a dead body.). Guest star, yes; extra, not really. 

Had bland for 10A, meaning bots for 10D and lop for 11D ... that didn't last! Also earth before ARBOR, which I'm sure I'm not alone on. 

Love the clues for MASON and EURO. That's the kind of thing I love-- tricky but when you get it, it clicks. Also the music appreciation one. 

Also love the theme! I left the theme entries blank until I knew the trick, and I think TAKEI was the first one to unlock for me (I did have the revealer at that point).

I actually loved this one. I figured it out at 26A with TAKE IT IN. That helped me figure out all of the other theme entries. Simeon is such a talented constructor. I vaguely remember the other puzzle he referenced in the constructor note. It was likely one of the first Lewis puzzles that I ever solved where I became a fan ☺️ Thank you for this, Simeon. You’ve gained a fan in me!

Really enjoyed this one.   A little easier than I prefer, but definitely kept me interested.  Got the theme before I got to the revealer, and had fun with the fill.  

And TIL why IPA is called IPA.

I decided not to worry about those pesky little asterisks and just go with the crosses if I got stuck and do what Simon sez.  He never let me down, and when the puzzle was almost done, I got it.  I don't know whether this is the sign of a great puzzle, or an easy one.  I think I'll go with the former.  

I'm seeing some IBEENHADs, but I don't AGREE (except for maybe ZORK).  Lots of skill to make it all work, and I wasn't even aware of where it was going until I got there.

Thank you, Mr. Siegel.  Come back soon.

Good puzzle.  Very good puzzle.

But it did have its ups and downs
This was outstanding. Once I figured out what was happening, I found myself hitting the What Goes Up line so I could speedrun the theme answers. Very well done!
not my favourite, but this was very, very clever. I'm proud of myself for identifying the theme and puzzling it out.
Nice and crunchy. Great Thursday puzzle. Thanks!
Etoile is the term they use in Paris for prima. There is even a new tv show with that name.

IT’S LOVE!  Such a clever theme and revealer, and one which I needed to successfully solve (I’m looking at you, ZORK). 

Great way to debut TONY AWARD, and with a brilliant clue to boot. Which reminds me, I like HEAVE HO.  

Fun plurals GENII and EMERITI. 

Danke, Simeon. That was fun.

I liked the theme and was able to figure it out quickly from the revealer, but got stuck with some of the other clues, some of which I thought were inaccurate. I agree with the criticism already made of PERP, DVR and ZORK; another one that I thought iffy is TONYAWARD, which I'd say is a theater award, not a music award (even though it has categories for musical theater). I thought the Juno Awards fit, given the crosses I had then, but I'm not sure if anyone has heard of them in the US! 🙂

I liked the ALIBABA clue, for which I had initially put *ISHMAEL (famous for mentioning his name in the opening line of Moby Dick, of course).

Loved it. So clever and so well constructed, the gentle downward placement of each of the themers, that they spelled out actual words or names (HESHE was a stretch), and obviously it led to things like KIROV, but what can a poor boy do? I thought the whole thing was first rate and that names you didn't know could get filled in by the crosses. There was always one "starter" clue in the clumps of harder ones, the clues that give you a foot in the door.

Who had ISHMAEL just as you were starting out before quickly going to ALI BABA? (Which was even better anyway). 

And it makes sense that Eli means "My God" -- I'm sure many a New York Giant fan, in that terrible season of 2018, was muttering, growling, shouting, "My God, won't somebody give Eli Manning the old heave ho?!!!!???"
I agree with people who don’t love I been had and DVR as answers but don’t agree with the whine otherwise. I thought it was challenging and fun.
I been bad!  Also terrible game.
If you have to rely on multiple long shot answers, not just one or two, but like five answers that are obviously a stretch…that’s a bad puzzle.

I’d love it if our stats could track the amount of time it takes us to solve a puzzle per individual constructor. 

I could be wrong, but I don’t think I’ve ever done a Simeon Seigel in less than an hour. (1:05 for this evening’s beast)

Really liked this puzzle but it was very hard for me.

I’m going to look back and check my time on previous Seigel puzzles.

Scratched my head for a couple of seconds about KLEE, but then assumed it must be pronounced "clay" which was confirmed in the column.

Completed the puzzle in 20% less time than average.  Figured out the theme with GAMERESERVES once I got the revealer.  Nice trick, enjoyed puzzling out the theme answers.  

I'm usually not so picky, but I think 30A needs an English lesson.

Proud to have thought of CINERAMA without any crosses, but really that only happened because I'm a boomer.

That was some great Thursday fiber and granola for my crossword guts today. 

Wonderful! Don’t want another 15 years to treat us again!
The clues/answers and theme felt more tortured than usual. Oh well, there's always tomorrow
500 bonus points for including ZORK, one of my favorite games growing up! Made the puzzle for me, very fun!

Anybody else remember when that 57a "early PC game" was a mainframe game with the definitely "sensical" name of Adventure?

I still remember "Do you expect to kill a dragon with your bare hands?" and "twisty little passages all alike".

Why am I suddenly feeling older than usual?

Got Klee quicklay. And thought I was off to the races. But then got to Suva which I wanted to spell Shiva and was certain it was a rebus puzzle which I felt was confirmed by first name in Russian ballet and had the OV and all I could think of was Baryshnikov and another sh which threw me off for a while

I just realized Lewis. I think that’s OUR Lewis. Got a shout out in the constructor notes. 

Also. I’m glad the constructor has a bunch of puzzles published already.  

Because could you imagine finding out your first puzzle made the cut. But had to wait 3+ years? To finally buy paper copies for your loved ones?

Wow I guess I’m in the minority today. I thought the theme was brilliantly constructed and the fill was good, I just thought the clueing was too easy. I didn’t give hardly anything a passing glance until the middle bottom, and that’s only because I forgot the Wizards were NBA not NHL and was looking for TUNE or TONE before TONYAWARD (terrific clue that). My only real nit was Stadia for Stadiums in the clue (made me think it would be something archaic, seriously who says stadia today?) and I didn’t mind I BEEN HAD but think it should have been signaled by something else non grammatical (They done got me! was my suggestion in an earlier post). I guess I got ALIBABA early on and was off to the races, but based on others’ reactions I was just on the constructor’s wavelength. But I have loads of appreciation for today’s puzzle.

"Do you like gravity?"
"Yeah, I'm down with that."

(That pun felt forced.)

welp, it scrambled my brain and it was more work than usual for me ~  
~ plus taking much longer to solve, even after i got the up and down trick

a couple of mild amusements along the way ~ 13D ETOILES for prima ballerinas was sweet and 43A EURO for capital on the mediterranean made me say “d’oh!”

having finished wednesday night is like getting out of school early

happy thursday, everyone!

Not knowing ZORK I spent what felt like an eternity trying to find the mistake until I realised that American spelling of ORGANISING would have a zed. 

😀😀

An excellent puzzle. 

I was wondering whatever happened to the ‘ve in being had (30A) but then again it is just a crossword.

Must say, I'm surprised at the backlash to 30A.

In casual conversation (at least mine), 'VE is often omitted.

"You been sitting on that sofa for a while!"

"Yeah, I been stuck on this puzzle for an hour!"

I can easily come up with a dozen more examples.

Brilliant puzzle. More yo-yo than so-so and definitely not no-no. 

My main takeaway: how on earth do you think of words that go up and down?

My personal flub: I got stuck on ZING, thinking it was SING, a bit of British Englishing.
I love tricky Thursdays and the more they hurt my brain the better. This was one of the better.
Autocheck wasn't much help tonight, except that I would never have gotten anywhere without it. I ran the whole alphabet with it at 57A/D. I'll try to figure out those two Z words tomorrow morning.
Yeah, nah.
Now that was tough. 23 minute solve, but streak is intact

I remember playing Zork on the Apple ][e back in the 1980s, and Infocom had refined it a bit more than the original game on The MIT computers. A text adventure, with limited descriptions and which allowed only two word commands, you had to do a lot of imagining to visualize where you were and what to do. In other words, good training for a Thursday puzzle.

I struggled a bit for a while until the revealer sunk in and I went back and found the theme answers that I was wondering about and saw the light. That made the last two a little easier. Also had REnegED instead of REVOKED for a while. which made the alternate spelling for ShIVA fit and got the NW finished.

Wasn't happy about the clue for PERP, because on shows like the First 48, the perps are prominent in the story and although the detectives are featured, there wouldn't be a show without the perps, they're definitely not "extras."

Anyway, I got it done, but I was a bit over my average, but any time I get to figure out the trick, I'm happy.

Thanks, Simeon!
Simeon Seigel never ever disappoints. Excellent Thursday.

I had the reveal fairly early on and eventually was about 3/4 done with two 5-letter themers to get. It was clear the ones I had weren’t jiving with their clues, and I wasn’t making the connection. 🤔 I’m trying too hard? What does George TAKEI have to do with it? So I took a break and on coming back saw BITTE become BITTER ENDERS. I saw the light 💡 and got the last two. Huzzah! My favorite was TONY AWARD.
I'm on a three-figure streak, but this is the first puzzle that made me want to end it. Deeply upsetting every which way. Pun and ire intended.
They have apps not DVRS and most likely an app that might work like a DVR! But with streaming who needs them anyway.

As Barry would say, I filled in this puzzle but did not solve it, lol.

Loved the fill and cluing. And a shout out to our beloved, departed Paul Allen, who spent millions restoring the CINERAMA theater—now the flagship venue of the Seattle International Film Festival—so that we can gather and watch movies together downtown on a glorious, huge screen in a gorgeous retro space.
One of those that at first seemed imcomprehensible, then just came together. In other words, the best kind.

It's always fun to come here and find out a lot of other people made the same initial wrong assumptions that I did: REnegED before REVOKED, bland before ICIER, ishmAel before ALIBABA, Nhl before NBA, and paNoRAMA before CINERAMA. Speaking of that last one, I remember when "This is Cinerama" was re-released in the 70s, and my parents took us to see it. I don't think it was shown in an actual Cinerama theater, but his was before IMAX, so it seemed very cool to us. https://youtu.be/vrzjdlyZCD8?si=2i1p9i4Nl5SMSMWO Here's an interesting tidbit from the Wikipedia article about Cinerama: "But it must be said that at the sides of his gigantic screen there is some distortion more noticeable in some parts of the house than in others." https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cinerama And that tidbit leads me to offer a PSA for anyone planning to ride Soarin' at Disney World or Soarin' Over California at Disneyland... You gotta sit in the middle! The ride has the same drawbacks that Cinerama had. If you sit on the sides, you get curved distortion. Also, if you want a more immersive experience, sit in the top row so you don't see people's feet dangling in front of you. And yes, you can request to wait for those particular seats to be available. Top/Center is the way to go. You're welcome! 😁
Arrgh! She were a rum 'un, she were! Like the waves and tides, this one has it's ups and downs. But I lashed meself to me desk and rode out the storm, barely avoiding a grounding or two. Arrgh!

Man, this is a tough week.  I've never heard of Kirov, Tseng, Zork, LiveRadar, iBeenHad ("I've been", sure, but not "I been").   Also, I had reneged for revoked, area for ward.   I somehow managed to come in at pretty much my exact average... But it felt a lot harder than average.

I like the twists and tricks of Thursdays but this was not my jam. IMHO the theme felt "forced." Plus that along with a lot of obscure names and  multiple entries that were borderline at best (IBEENHAD - not a thing, DVR- smart TVs dont have em and PERP is almost assuredly NOT an extra)
This one just wasnt for me... Looking forward to a nice themeless Friday palate cleanser tomorrow
KLEE does not sound like clay though…

I got thrown off by putting EGOISTS for prima ballerinas. 

My sincere apologies to all ballerinas out there.
Pistachios, yes! Chocolate, not so much, Deb 😉 YMMV
Not the puzzle to start while nodding off...closed my eyes to ponder a clue and I was out.  After a bit of sleep it all came together.  Thanks for the puzzle Simeon!

If a fan of this puzzle and relatively new to the NYT XWord, I recommend checking out Lewis Rothlein’s (“our Lewis”) Sunday puzzle of 5/31/2020, a collaboration with Jeff Chen. All of Lewis’s puzzles are gems, so they’re all worth seeking out if you have not yet done. You can see the dates of his puzzles here: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Author/Lewis_Rothlein (Lewis, please venmo my fee to prreppuzzlemucker. Thanks!)
another entertaining Thursday puzzle.   CINERAMA brought back childhood memories of going to the movies back in the sixties.

Lots of clever clues - maybe non-Americans think of ALI BABA before Ishmael? 
The trick was also such clever construction, though I didn't get it, hardly ever do, but appreciate the skill.

Never heard of DVR, I'm so non-technical. 

The section with ZING, ZORK, NBA, SERTAS, ARBOR - not ever heard of any of them! 

No ARBOR day here, and I've never noticed mattress brand names.

Yet I managed to fill them all in with crossers and guesses - that's a well-made crossword for me.

Nice to see ZORK make it into a puzzle almost exactly a month (July 18) after it was my initial guess for [Pioneering puzzle laden computer game] (the actual answer to that one being the equally valid MYST).

I wonder if grues can be kept sated and at bay with a supply of sacrificial Oreos and emus.

I caught on to the trick before the revealer with GAME RESERVES, so I thought this would be a breeze.  Luckily, there were a number of unknowns for me, so I still got a nice Thursday workout.  I even had the opportunity to use the trick for ZORK and for the spelling of EMERITI.  

The last section to fall for me was the area containing TOUCH, ERIE, CINERAMA, and EURO.  I had panoRAMA, fell for the misdirect of [Capital...], was convinced that the lake was in Ireland, and wasn't seeing that meaning of [Graze].  I sorted it out once I decided that the lake is almost always ERIE.

One thing that delights me about today's puzzle is that if it had been cued differently, it could have been a delicious  Wednesday puzzle. And that, my friends, is no chopped LIVER.  Or any other ORGAN for that matter.

To those commenters who mentioned the puzzle I made with Jeff Chen that was referred to in Simeon's notes (and thank you, @PM for those kind words) -- yes, a bit of déjà vu at coming across today's theme.

But please note that Simeon's notes make it clear that he came upon this theme on his own, independently.  And when I realize, even in this small instance, that his mind and my mind thought alike, he with his Hall of Fame inventive mind, well, that humbles and thrills me to no end.

I had such good luck with the crosses that I was a good way in, paid scant attention to TAKEI and GAMER, and wondered, "Where's the trick?" .  Got to BITTE and decided I'd better pay closer attention.  

I scanned the comments - I can't be the only one who was looking for the missing half of the reveal (MUSTCOMEDOWN)? 

First class puzzling.  Many thanks.

Cool. I turned the corner on this gimmick at 17A. 
Lewis will love the palindromic flavor of today's trick.

Haven't read the column yet, but I see Deb's photo of a pile of fortune cookie slips. I collect them. Sometimes deep, sometimes mundane or poetic or funny.

One in my wallet now, so probably less than a year old, is 

It's doing good with what you've got that lights the morning star.

(yes, it works with "in bed".)

Got any favorite fortunes?

Well, Simeon’s inventive themes can hide his constructing prowess.  Note that not only are today’s gimmick answers hard to come up with, they are symmetrically placed, very hard to pull off.  Bravo!  

But grid-building skill always takes second seat to “How was the solve?”  

To me, a wordplay lover, this rocked.  Look at those clues for ALI BABA, EURO, MASON, ADAGE, ICIER, STAND, and TONY AWARD.  (Those last four are orinal, BTW.)

To me, who relishes overcoming adversity, there were plenty of trip-ups to unriddle.  

To me who loves to have memories re-kindled, STAND had me flashing on the incredibly heavy music stands from when I played in a middle school band.  

To me, who loves beauty and fun in answer, there was SEAWEED WRAP, ZORK, HEAVE HO, EMERITI, ZING, and KEEPERS.  

To me, who loves serendipities, sharing the grid was TIN and a backward TINS.

How was the solve?  As usual, with your puzzles, Simeon, this was sublime.  Thank you!
Great Thursday.  Took me a while, but so worth it.

I started out confidently, filling in 2D with ISHMAEL, happy I was on the same wavelength as the constructor. Although that wasn't at all the case, I did eventually see the trick and really enjoyed the solve.

Great puzzle.
Awwww, Deb!  What a wonderful story!  Thanks for giving us all a feel-good for the day.  <3

Deb,

I knew my husband was a KEEPER when the first time she met him, Stripes (my kitty) jumped up and sat on his lap.

She usually hid under my bed when anyone came over.  

She knew he was special.

Chapter Two of a 
Rothstein, Chen, Seigel puzzle.

Triple-whammy joy.
Double take on a brilliant theme
and gorgeous construction.

Love.
Love.
Love.
Took a while, but great puzzle

I'm mulling over whether ICIER really does answer the clue [Needing more salt] properly.  Of course, like others, I went for BLAND first, and when IBMS seemed likely, and CIA was a certainty, I switched to ICIER and moved on.

We all know the rule about parallelism in clues and answers; plurals go with plurals, past tense with past tense, etc.  ICIER seems on the surface (pun intended) to work that way here, with an -ER ending, and "more" in the clue.

But doesn't [Needing more salt, perhaps] really only signal ICY?  After all, if I salt my walk and it's still ICY, doesn't it need more salt?

Putting it another way, doesn't ICIER imply "in need of salt more (than something else)" instead, as if to say, my walk needs salt more than yours does; my walk is ICIER than yours, because it sits beneath a drippy eave, and yours doesn't?  Doesn't the phrasing of the clue in the puzzle imply a comparison with another walk?

I hope I'm expressing the difference clearly, because I just think this clue is a little off.

The tough week continues for me. This was a great, well constructed puzzle but way over my head. I do struggle to ‘see’ unusual word layouts; even after Deb’s excellent explanation I still stared, squinted, stood on one leg etc and failed to see most of the theme answers.
The non-theme answers were fairly straightforward, though I always want to spell SIVA with the anglicised H. Or is that a different deity altogether?  TIL ZORK plus what the heck is a DVR?
Gotta say, as a Thursday curmudgeon, that this was as good as they get. Very clever construction, tricky cluing, and unknowns ultimately solvable from the crosses.

Saw the theme very early with TAKEI(TIN). Solved this puzzle unaided, though it took almost thirty minutes. To me, an example of a puzzle in which the theme was insufficient to compensate for other flaws.

First, BITTE(RENDER) seems contrived and forced. And then we have a lot of proper nouns (some striking me a rather obscure), as well as the awkward IBEENHAD and HESHE.

I liked "Needing more salt, perhaps" for ICIER (not BLAND). But, all in all, not a puzzle that I enjoyed solving.
Thank you for setting the record straight with regard to pronouns. We seem to have lost our way.
Not in my wheelhouse. It would have been better if the revealer said something to point to the end of the answers. I started looking to ‘go up’ with the start of the words.
This just felt like a chore to me.  Admittedly the theme was clever but the whole thing was hard work and not in a fun way

37-Across should be DOMI, the plural of DOMUS, since the clue gives "stadia" in Latin.

For those of you who can't see me through your screens, my tongue is firmly planted in my cheek. ;-)
I spent a while wondering who Tonya Ward was.
I done did this puzz
As someone who is usually lukewarm on Thursday shenanigans, let me say this puzzle was an absolute pleasure. What a treat!
I usually find Thursday puzzles to be somewhat aggravating and clever for clever's sake but this was a fun one.  The "tricks" made sense and still made me go over my average solving time.

I am fond of puzzles where the answers turn corners, go upside down, etc. So I like today’s.
Still, I can recall a time when I was new to solving and a trick like today’s would have wowed me utterly.
Am I becoming jaded and blasé?

Now waiting for the puzzle in which the answers, instead of just doing fun things in two dimensions, somehow jump out into a third dimension.  Simeon, you up for that?

This is the most tedious slog ever written. The theme itself was fine and on par for a Thursday.
Bunch of random titles and names serving no purpose. Icier is not even a tad clever. Zork, bitte, kirov, etoilles, tseng... "I been had" indeed. (Please use proper English next time... Thanks!)
What an absolute waste of time.
I can't remember a crossword answer that has ever made me as mad as I BEEN HAD.

I am studying classical guitar. I've just moved beyond the more basic pieces and am currently working on Tárrega's "Adelita." The infamous twelveth measure that has a barre chord and an ornament that asks for an impossible (for me, at this stage) reach has me really discouraged. My lesson is at two o'clock, and one again I will show up having made zero progress. I was seriously thinking of just giving up the guitar.

I just did this puzzle and read the commentary, which includes the phrase "has a good beat and you can dance to it," which is a link. I hit the link; it links to an article which talks about the phrase as used on the TV show "American Bandstand." But...

I continued to the rest of the article. IT'S ABOUT THE DIFFICULTY OF PLAYING BARRE CHORDS ON THE GUITAR, AND CONTAINS THE PHRASE "DON'T GIVE UP."

What are the odds?

So, OK...I'll go see my world-class instructor today, tell her what's going on, bring her my copy of Segreras exercises, and plead for help. But I won't give up.

I was wracking my brain for the word for an alternative interpretation for 20A--the one that means one horizontal line of bricks. I was just about to post an impassioned plea to this community to help me out (with all you word-nerds out there, someone would have known, right?)
  But then it popped up:
      COURSE
Endlessly fascinating how the brain works.

Yikes! Twenty minutes over average - I just could not see the theme for the longest time. It's probably an experience thing - more experienced solvers probably know which pattern is being referred to by the revealer - rebus, substitution, directional? 

I thought I had it when TAKEI became TAKEIN (which sort of works with the clueing) by turning downwards - clearly we needed to "MUSTGODOWN" on the starred clues. Got it. Except I didn't. 

SKIRT and TINYAWARD cross were the last error to finally fall. 

I'm exhausted.
Came here for the complaints.  I was not disappointed.   Personally, I liked this puzzle.
Very enjoyable puzzle. But I had hoped the gravity saying was some version of "but it's the law".

Seems I hit a few nerves yesterday with my comments. Sorry to say today won’t be much better. Really quite a miserable one, huh?

It really is something when a constructor scours Google for random obscure trivia to throw into a puzzle just to make it “harder”. Many of you will defend that, and that’s your choice. I say it’s cheap.

Speaking of cheap, we come to the beloved Thursday trickery that so many seem to fawn over. Well, I actually thought today’s was extremely clever, and a neat twist on the crossword idea. Unfortunately, I don’t think it fully worked, as, per usual, the horizontal words were complete throwaways when solving, and, having nothing to do with the written clue, became another sad cheap trick at difficulty. Again, though, I know how many of you like that kind of thing.

Finally, the cluing. I found some of it appropriate while some other clues completely mind boggling. Truly not sure what goes on at NYT Games editorial to allow some of these to pass, but I suppose standards can’t always be up to snuff.

I look forward to the deluge of comments from the valiant defenders of the NYT Crossword comments section. If I were you, I would take a long look at why you’re so quick to defend mediocrity rather than ask for better.

By weird coincidence, yesterday, I was planning to take a day trip to Kelleys Island! Printed the ferry schedule out and all, but the day looked cloudy and cool, and threatened rain, so I decided to postpone. 
Frankly, not all that much there, but there are a couple interesting geological and ecological sites: a monumental set of limestone grooves, carved out by glaciers--when I was a small child, one could climb on them, but that's not permitted anymore (probably never was.) Also, lakeside alvars--natural limestone "pavement," with just enough soil to sustain some scrubby, alpine plant life. Once again, I think they're considered a "fragile" ecosystem, and one is not supposed to climb on them, but everyone does, to picnic, and go swimming in the lake off of them.

Also, the ferry is kind of a rip off--there's only one, so it's a monopoly--no discount for a round trip ticket (I mean, who would buy a one-way ticket, unless you were mortally ill and wished to end one's days on the North Shore Alvar)--PLUS they charge you to bring a bike on the ferry, AND they charge you to park the car on their lot. (But I found a way around THAT: park, about a mile a way, at the nearby Marblehead Lighthouse State Historical Site [free], and bike down to the ferry.

Love your story, Deb! 🩵 When did I know my husband was a KEEPER, you ask?! When we were in our first year or so of dating, I was driving (he usually did) and I had my hand lightly on his leg (shocking, I know!) and my favorite song came on the radio. I have a long and glorious history of being overly enthusiastic (who, me!?) about the song—Juke Box Hero by Foreigner. So, in normal HeathieS (as I was known at the time) fashion, I turned up the volume and started rocking out with some mild head banging, my long hair flying, basically pounding on his leg like a drum, as I sang the entire song at very near the top of my lungs.... yes, while still driving. I was just a kid of 32, I didn't know any better! Har! 

Anyhow, it ends and he said, "Wow, that was really nice, babe! Seems like you really like that song." 🤣 But the main KEEPER thing is that he didn't open the door and roll out... risking death to save himself—and he kept asking me out. Enthusiasm aside, I am not what you call a good singer.

Wonderful to see Zork here. During my sophomore-year summer, I was honored to work as a beta tester for a game written by one of the Infocom authors, Steve Meretzky. He hadn’t personally worked on Zork (to my knowledge, anyway), but he was a part of the text-adventure team that brought those wonderful little puzzle boxes to market. 

And those early games! I remember staying up with my older brother, too enthralled to turn on the lights for hours after the sun had gone down, trying to piece together puzzle after puzzle—raising the waters at the dam, traversing the coal mine and Hades, and saying “Hello Sailor” in location after locations, hoping in vain that it might work magic.

@Cat Lady Margaret

I submitted a puzzle once where the revealer was CYLINDRICAL and the clue was “the shape of this puzzle when manipulated properly”. The left and right hand clues were 3-4 letters long and while each was a legitimate crossword fill on its own, they made a different word when shaped into a cylinder and the ends met. The clue for the right side was the beginning of the clue for that word and the clue for the left side was the end of that word, with ellipses to suggest they continued on. So for example the right hand entry might be IMP and clued as “African ant…”, the left hand “ALA” and clued as “…elope” and if you folded it into a cylinder the entire clue would be “African antelope” —IMPALA. I thought it was pretty ingenious but turned down by the editors because it was too “out of the box” literally, and thank God they did because I’d probably need therapy from all the hate I would have gotten in the comments. But there you go.

I wasn't sure what they were called either but I asked my AI thingy if we should use suffixes with dates:

Using suffixes like "st," "nd," "rd," and "th" in dates is a matter of style, and different contexts call for different approaches.

When to Use Suffixes
You should use suffixes when the date is written out in a sentence, and it's being read aloud. This is common in more formal or literary writing.

Examples:

"The meeting is scheduled for October 21st."

"She was born on the 3rd of May."

"We met on the 1st of January."

When to Omit Suffixes
In most professional, business, or casual contexts, it's standard practice to omit the suffixes. This is especially true for digital communication, forms, and official documents where clarity and conciseness are prioritized.

Examples:

10/21/2025

October 21, 2025

"The deadline is October 21, 2025."

"Final report due: May 3."

In summary, for formal writing in a sentence, the suffix is correct. For all other practical purposes, especially in a digital context, it's best to leave it out.

@John Carson generally for signage, less is more. So I wouldn't say "the 22nd." I would say "Aug 22."
